action.action-desc: Mr. Grothman (for himself, Ms. Mace, and Mr. Griffith) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and Labor

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Student and Teacher Safety Act of 2022.

subsection.header: Student support and academic enrichment grants
subsection.text: Subpart 1 of part A of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7111 et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating sections 4109 through 4112 as sections 4110 through 4113, respectively; and
by inserting after section 4108 the following:

section.header: Activities to support school safety and prevent violence against students or school personnel
section.text: Each local educational agency, or consortium of such agencies, that receives an allocation under section 4105(a) may use such funds for school safety infrastructure improvements to prevent, mitigate, or respond to incidents of violence.

subsection.text: Section 4102 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7112) is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (5)(B), by inserting including the prevention of gun violence, after school safety,;
by redesignating paragraphs (7) and (8) as paragraphs (8) and (9), respectively; and
by inserting after paragraph (6) the following:

The term school safety infrastructure improvements means improvements to the physical facility or technology of a school to prevent intruders from entering a school, ensure students and school personnel may safely enter the school building and exit during an emergency, or protect the life and well-being of students and school personnel, including—

subparagraph.text: physical improvements to the school to prevent and deter unauthorized access to the school, including locks, double entry systems, hardened entrances, and interior and exterior video surveillance systems;
security doors, automatic locks, security glass, alarm systems, metal detectors, and sensor systems;
emergency communications systems, including wireless and geographically precise mobile alert systems;
perimeter fencing;
emergency exit systems;
duress or panic systems;
emergency tip lines; and
any other physical improvements to existing facilities where the primary purpose is to improve or enhance school safety.

subsection.text: Section 4103(a) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7113(a)) is amended, in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking section 4112 and inserting section 4113.
Section 4104(b)(3)(B) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7114(b)(3)(B)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (iii), by striking and at the end; and
by adding at the end the following:

clause.text: improving the safety and security of schools, which may include—

subclause.text: identifying and disseminating best practices for school safety;
assisting in the establishment or implementation of emergency planning, which may include emergency response teams to address emergencies at schools;

establishing or identifying agreements with local law enforcement and health agencies, including nonprofit, public, and private mental health agencies and institutions, to improve coordination of services and identify threats to the safety of students and school personnel; and

subsection.header: Activities To support safe and healthy students
subsection.text: Section 4108 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7118) is amended—

paragraph.text: in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking Subject to and inserting the following:
in subsection (a)(5) (as amended by paragraph (1))—

subparagraph.text: in subparagraph (B), in the matter preceding clause (i), by striking 4111 and inserting 4112; and
in subparagraph (E), by striking 4111 and inserting 4112; and

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed to—

paragraph.text: prevent Federal, State, or local law enforcement from detaining or arresting an individual who could otherwise be detained or arrested for an alleged violent offense;
otherwise interfere with Federal, State, or local law enforcement’s discretion to investigate legitimate threats to school safety; or
discourage school officials from referring an individual to law enforcement.

paragraph.text: A local

subparagraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: The limitation described in paragraph (1) shall not apply to technology infrastructure that is also a school safety infrastructure improvement.
